name: John Adams
subtitle: Angliae totius tabula cum distancii notoribus in itinerantium usum accommodata
paragraph: A travel map of England showing distances between cities arranged for the use of travelers. Network diagram on a map.

name: Adriano Balbi
subtitle: L'état de l'instruction et du nombre des crimes
paragraph: The first comparative choropleth thematic maps, showing crimes against persons and crimes against property in relation to level of instruction by departments in France, with André-Michel Guerry.

name: Heinrich Berghaus
subtitle: Physikalischer Atlas
paragraph: One of the most extensive and detailed thematic atlases, an illustration of Alexander von Humboldt's Cosmos. With distribution of plants, animals, and climate. Most of the maps contained tables, graphs, pictorial profiles of distributions over altitude, and other visual accompaniments including cross sectional diagrams.

name: Charles Booth
subtitle: Inquiry into Life and Labour in London
paragraph: Early example of social cartography, each street is colored to indicate the income and social class of its inhabitants. Updated and expanded 1889 first edition to 12 sheets total. Published  in the survey volumes between 1902 and 1903.

name: Henry Pickering Bowditch
work: Board of Health of the State of Massachusetts
subtitle: Relation of height to weight in Boston schoolboys
paragraph: Extensive survey of 24,500 children. Early ideas of correlation and curvilinear regression across many charts.

name: Arthur L. Bowley
subtitle: Elements of Statistics
paragraph: Early statistical textbook with graphical analysis of time-series data showing that while the initial series showed wide variability, moving averages made the series progressively smoother.

name: Heinrich Wilhelm Brandes
subtitle: *1905 reconstruction shown
paragraph: Set of weather maps "hindcasted" for each day of the year 1783. Plotted air pressure values and then drew isobars, lines of equal air pressure, by hand.

name: Jean-Étienne Guettard
subtitle: Engraved by Philippe Buache
paragraph: First map to show bands or zones of surface geological similarity. With symbols to identify  locations of different rocks and minerals.

name: Philippe Buache
work: Physical Map or Natural Geography of France
subtitle: Carte Physique ou Géographie Naturelle de la France
paragraph: Early contour map. Details of English Channel suggest modern nautical charts.

name: Émile Cheysson
subtitle: Across 200 Years
paragraph: First cartogram, using a deformation of spatial size to show a quantitative variable: the decrease in time to travel from Paris to various places in France over 200 years.

name: August Friedrich Wilhelm Crome
subtitle: Groessen Karte von Europa
paragraph: One of the first comparison diagrams: superimposed squares compare land areas of European states. He updated it  in 1818 (and incorporated Playfair's pie chart).

name: Charles Darwin
subtitle: "B" Notebook
paragraph: Vision for diverging adaptation as genealogical branching from a common ancestor. Refined and eventually published in 'On the Origin of the Species' (1859).

name: W.E.B. Du Bois
subtitle: The Exhibit of American Negroes
paragraph: Spiral diagram highlights the dramatic majority of Georgia African Americans who live outside cities (red).

name: Jacques Barbeu-Dubourg
subtitle: Carte (et Machine) Chronographique
paragraph: An annotated timeline of history (from Creation) on a 54-foot continuous scroll, including names and descriptive events, grouped thematically, with symbols denoting character and profession.

name: Baron Pierre Charles Dupin
subtitle: Carte figurative de l'instruction populaire de la France
paragraph: First choropleth map. Darker shadings indicate lower student density. Used to argue for Northern industriousness.

name: Charles Louis de Fourcroy
subtitle: Essai d'une table poléométrique
paragraph: Use of geometric, proportional figures (squares) to compare demographic quantities by superposition, an early "tableau graphique."

name: Jean Baptiste Joseph Fourier
subtitle: Recherches Statistique sur La Ville de Paris
paragraph: Cumulative frequency curve, named 'ogive' by Galton for resemblance to curved point of gothic arch. Shows inhabitants of Paris by age groupings.

name: Benjamin Franklin
subtitle: Franklin-Folger Chart
paragraph: First map of the Gulf Stream, which gave it its name. More popular 1785 version shown. Named for mariner (and Franklin cousin) Timothy Folger's contributions. Produced so to dissuade British mail packets from sailing against the current.

name: Francis Galton
subtitle: Meteorographica
paragraph: Similar air pressure and barometric changes are shown with standard icons. Enabled discovery of anti-cyclonic movement of wind around low-pressure.

name: Francis Galton
subtitle: (papers)
paragraph: Galton's first semi-graphic scatterplot and correlation diagram, of head size and height, from his notebook on Special Peculiarities.

name: Francis Galton
work: Regression towards mediocrity in hereditary stature
subtitle: Diagram based on Table I
paragraph: Galton's first illustration of the idea of correlation, using sizes of the seeds of mother and daughter plants.

name: William R. Gardner
work: Comparative Heights of the Principal Mountains and Lengths of the Principal Rivers
subtitle: with William Darton
paragraph: Rivers are stretched out in single lines, with the longest on the left combining with the shortest mountains, while the shortest rivers combine with the highest mountains on the right. First of its kind that defined a cartographic style.

name: Josiah Willard Gibbs
subtitle: Trilinear Plot
paragraph: First use of trilinear coordinates (graphs of x-y-z where x+y+z=constant), and other graphical methods applied to explain fundamental relations in thermodynamics including diagrams of entropy vs. temperature.

name: William Mitchell Gillespie
subtitle: The New York Times, May 19
paragraph: Early example of a slopegraph, encoding 181 variables across 60 years. Gillespie introduced many charts to the newspaper across the 1850s, helping found data journalism.

name: André-Michel Guerry
subtitle: with physiological phenomena
paragraph: First polar-area charts. Shows frequency of meteorological data as cyclic phenomena.

name: Ernst Haeckel
subtitle: Monophyletischer Stambaum der Organismen
paragraph: Popularized a reformed morphology with evolution as the organising principle of a cosmic synthesis unifying science, religion, and art.

name: Edmond Halley
work: An Historical Account of the Trade Winds, and Monsoons
subtitle: Observable in the Seas between and near the Tropicks, with an Attempt to Assign the Phisical Cause of the Said Wind
paragraph: First meteorological map. Charts directions of world trade winds and monsoons.

name: Edmond Halley
work: An Estimate of the Degrees of the Mortality of Mankind
subtitle: Fig. 7 (Halley's Diagram)
paragraph: First use of areas of rectangles to display probabilities of independent binary events (Halley's diagram). Proposed in the context of multivariate demographic data. Foundation for a more complex three-dimensional 'rectangled Parallelepipedon.'

name: Edmond Halley
work: Height of the Mercury in the Barometer
subtitle: Fig. 5 (Bivariate Plot)
paragraph: Bivariate plot of a theoretical curve derived from observations (barometric pressure vs. altitude). Graphical analysis based on empirical data.

name: Edmond Halley
work: Sea-Chart of the Western & Southern OCEAN
subtitle: shewing the Variations of the COMPASS
paragraph: Isogonic map, lines of equal magnetic declination for the world.  Possibly the first contour map of a data-based variable.

name: Henry Drury Harness
subtitle: Irish Railway Commission Atlas
paragraph: First published flow maps, showing transportation by means of shaded lines, widths proportional to number of passengers.

name: Alexander von Humboldt
subtitle: of Metropolises and Colonies in 1804
paragraph: Stacked bar graph shows the relative size of land areas (fat bars) and populations (skinny bars) in the New World, organized by European colonizing country. Note dramatic flourish of USA breaking off from other British colonies.

name: Alexander von Humboldt
subtitle: Carte des lignes isothermes
paragraph: First graph of isotherms (a term Humboldt coined), showing mean temperature around the world by latitude & longitude. Shows that temperature depends on latitude and altitude, a subscripted graph shows the direct relation of temperature to these two variables. Revolutionized physical geography and all future thematic mapping.

name: Christiaan Huygens
subtitle: From letter to brother Lodewijk
paragraph: First graph of a continuous distribution function. Data are from Graunt's life table, with age on the horizontal axis and number of survivors of the original birth cohort on the vertical axis. Part of a discussion of how to determine life expectancy for a person of given age.

name: Athanasius Kircher
subtitle: Tabula Geographico-Hydrographica Motus Oceani
paragraph: Landmark world map of ocean currents, first published in Kircher's Mundus Subterraneus, which advanced his theory that tides and currents are caused by water moving to and from a massive subterranean ocean.

name: Leon Lalanne
subtitle: Appendix Plate 1.
paragraph: Contour map of a 3D table: temperature x hour x month. Published in Kaemtz's METEOROLOGY, which also includes first logarithmic grid.

name: Johann Heinrich Lambert
subtitle: ou sur la mesure de l'humidité
paragraph: "A diagram does incomparably better service here than a table." Developed theory of measurement error by showing deviations from regular graphed line in study of humidity, first described in Neues Organon (1764).

name: Giovanni Maria Lancisi
work: On the noxious effluvia of marshes
subtitle: and their remedies
paragraph: Argument with an annotated map that mosquito-infested swamps are the breeding ground for malaria. Recommends draining swamps and cultivating forests.

name: Michael Florent van Langren
subtitle: Grados de la Longitud
paragraph: First (known) graph of statistical data. Created to explain the magnitude of the longitude problem. Shows the wide range of estimates of the distance in longitude between Toledo and Rome across a dozen maps. Dates to 1628 correspondence, formally presented in 1644.

name: Wilhelm Lexis
work: Introduction to the Theory of Population Statistics
subtitle: Einleitung in die Theorie der Bevölkerungsstatistik
paragraph: "Lexis diagram" showing relations among age, calendar time, and life spans of individuals simultaneously. Created at a time when multiple demographers were making similar charts.

name: Toussaint Loua
subtitle: Résumé graphique général de l'atlas statistique de la population de Paris
paragraph: First-known use of a semi-graphic table to display a data table by shading levels.

name: William Maclure
subtitle: APS Transactions Vol. IV.
paragraph: Maclure began the self-imposed task of making a geological survey of the U.S. in 1807, crossing the Allegheny Mountains ~50 times and covering nearly every state. He produced the largest geological map of its kind to date, earning him the honored title of 'Father of American Geology.'

name: Étienne-Jules Marey
subtitle: Chronophotographic illustration
paragraph: Invention of chronophotographic gun, the precursor of motion-picture cameras. It recorded a series of 12 consecutive frames a second, with all the frames recorded on the same picture. Used to study natural motion of animals and people.

name: Étienne-Jules Marey
work: Fig. 5 - Chart of train operation on a railway
subtitle: The graphical method
paragraph: With engineer Ibry. Graphic representation of a train schedule showing rate of travel along the route from Paris to Lyon. Recent evidence suggests that Lt. Sergev had developed this method approximately 30 years earlier in Russia.

name: Edward Walter Maunder
work: Distribution of Spot Centres in Latitude
subtitle: with Annie Maunder
paragraph: Use of the "butterfly diagram'' to study the variation of sunspots over time, leading to the discovery that they were markedly reduced in frequency from 1645-1715 (later named the Maunder minimum').

name: Georg von Mayr
work: J. of the Royal Bavarian Statistical Bureau
subtitle: Figure VII: Line charts in circles
paragraph: Early demonstration of 'radar chart' polar diagram for data representation.

name: Georg von Mayr
work: J. of the Royal Bavarian Statistical Bureau
subtitle: Figure XII: Flat charts in polgon
paragraph: Early use of star plot for data representation.

name: Georg von Mayr
work: J. of the Royal Bavarian Statistical Bureau
subtitle: Figure VIII: Flat diagram with subdivisions
paragraph: Early use of proportional, divided square in the modern mosaic form.

name: Georg von Mayr
work: J. of the Royal Bavarian Statistical Bureau
subtitle: Figure XIX (Horses, Cattle)
paragraph: Two variable color map showing the joint density of horses (red) and cattle (green) in Bavaria.

name: Daniel McCallum
subtitle: Diagram Representing a Plan of Organization
paragraph: First formal organizational chart, designed to allow management of a business that was becoming unwieldy in its size and act as a directory for the new telegraph. Drafted by G.H. Henshaw.

name: Dmitri Mendeleev
subtitle: On the relations of the properties to the atomic weights of the elements.
paragraph: Used to classify chemical elements according to their properties, allowing the prediction of new elements that would be discovered later. Published in Zeitschrift für Chemie.

name: Charles Joseph Minard
subtitle: Carte Figurative ... Viandes de Boucherie
paragraph: Map incorporating statistical diagrams: pie charts proportional to consumption and colored by type of meat.

name: Charles Joseph Minard
work: Successive Losses of Men of the French Army
subtitle: in the Campaign of Russia 1812-1813
paragraph: Part of a pair of military history graphics possibly created as an anti-war commentary on the eve of the looming Prussian invasion. The last major work by Minard before his death after fleeing Paris.

name: Léon Montigny
subtitle: Les Élections Parisiennes, 1869
paragraph: Election map of Paris, showing the breakdown of votes by parties. Napoleon III's defeat in the elections of 1869 forced him to seek domestic political legitimacy through international conflict. The changing political tide  would lead to domestic turmoil, and eventually to a major international war and the fall of the Second French Empire.

name: Armand Joseph Frère de Montizon
subtitle: Carte Philosophique figurant La Population de la France
paragraph: First simple dot map of population by jurisdiction, with 1 dot = 10,000 people, producing a visual display of population density.

name: Michael George Mulhall
subtitle: Dictionary of Statistics
paragraph: Pictogram used to represent data by sizing icons proportional to a number. One of many fun figures across this clever dictionary.

name: Eadweard Muybridge
subtitle: "Sallie Gardner," owned by Leland Stanford
paragraph: Photographic series Horse In Motion was an early example of both small multiples and photo visualization.

name: Florence Nightingale
work: Diagram of the Causes of Mortality
subtitle: Mortality of the British army
paragraph: Several statistics-enhancing charts, including this famous polar-area diagram, together used to successfully argue for social and health reforms. Packaged in a colorful publication nicknamed the "coxcomb." Aided the introduction of modern nursing to the world.

name: Maurice d' Ocagne
subtitle: Coordonnées parallèles et axiales
paragraph: First alignment diagrams. Uses sets of parallel axes, rather than axes at right angles, in development of the essential ideas used in parallel coordinates plots. First of many figures shown.

name: John Ogilby
subtitle: "An Illustration of the Kingdom of England"
paragraph: First comprehensive road atlas, consisting of 100 plates. Innovations include establishing the scale of one inch to the mile, the consistent use of the standard mile, and an iconic scroll format popular for hundreds of years after and revitalized in the design of this interactive.

name: Luigi Perozzo
work: Absolute Number of Live Male Births
subtitle: Numero Assoluto dei Nati Vivi Maschi
paragraph: Stereogram (three-dimensional population pyramid) modeled on actual data (Swedish census, 1750-1875).

name: William Playfair
subtitle: Exports and Imports of SCOTLAND
paragraph: The first bar chart not tethered to time (e.g. Priestley's bars representing lifespans). Necessitated by not having historic data for Scotland, it constitutes a pure solution to the problem of discrete quantitative comparison.

name: William Playfair
subtitle: Exports and Imports to and from Denmark & Norway from 1700 to 1780
paragraph: First times series line graph including all elements we now take for granted: graduated and labeled axes, grid lines, title, annotations, lines indicating changes in the data over time, color to categorize different categories and highlight differences.

name: William Playfair
subtitle: Cities of Europe in the order of their Population
paragraph: First bubble chart. Represents city population with area of circle.

name: William Playfair
subtitle: Extent, Population & Revenues
paragraph: First pie chart. Used to show area of empires across different continents. Also contains first "Venn"-like diagram in margin to deal with complexities of German Empire. Also contains proto-slopegraph, showing changes in population.

name: Robert Plot
subtitle: Philosophical Transactions Numb: 169
paragraph: Recorded barometric pressure in Oxford every day of 1684. Based on work by Martin Lister.

name: James Cowles Prichard
subtitle: Africa (1 of 6 continent maps)
paragraph: First ethnographic maps, promoting 'Natural History of Man.' Africa's color key identifies 31 different races.

name: Joseph Priestley
subtitle: (redacted version shown)
paragraph: Timeline chart in which individual bars are used to visualize the life spans of 2,000 famous people, from 1200 B.C. to 1750 A.D. The chart was a commercial success, leading to over a dozen printings, an honorary doctorate for Priestley, and widespread attention to the emerging field of data visualization.

name: Joseph Priestley
subtitle: A View of the Principal Revolutions of Empire that have taken place in the World
paragraph: Building on the success of his Chart of Biography, Priestley shows the history of empires, illustrating his belief that the entire world's history was significant, with the goal to "help to the knowledge of history, impressing the imagination indelibly with a just image of the rise, progress, extent, duration, and contemporary state of all the considerable empires that have ever existed in the world."

name: Adolphe Quetelet
work: Curves indicating the tendency to crime
subtitle: in men (M) and women (M')
paragraph: Curves drawn from empirical data showing propensity to crime for both sexes: men peak earlier.

name: Adolphe Quetelet
subtitle: Letters on the Theory of Probability
paragraph: Results of sampling from model urns shown as symmetrical histograms, with limiting "curve of possibility'' (later called the normal curve).

name: Matthew Henry Phineas Riall Sankey
subtitle: Proceedings of The Institution of Civil Engineers
paragraph: Used Sankey diagram named (but not invented by him) in a figure showing the energy efficiency of a steam engine.

name: Christoph Scheiner
subtitle: Rosa Ursina, or the Sun
paragraph: The motion of sunspots over time. First known use of small multiples to show a series of images in a coherent display.

name: Valentine Seaman
subtitle: Plate I. (of two)
paragraph: First maps of the incidence of disease, using dots to show individual occurrences of yellow fever in waterfront areas of NYC.

name: Lt. Serjev
subtitle: Map, Schedule, Freight Tariffs
paragraph: Graphic representation of a train schedule for 35 railways stations, between St. Petersburg and Moscow. Top panel contains altitude above the Baltic Sea. Rediscovered in 1993 by Bart Bielawski.

name: William Smith
subtitle: of England & Wales with Part of Scotland
paragraph: The first nationwide geological map, setting the pattern for geological cartography, and founding stratigraphic geology.

name: John Snow
subtitle: On the Mode of Communication of Cholera
paragraph: Use of a map to display epidemiological data. Used to communicate the nature of the disease by highlighting the source of the 1854 Broad Street cholera epidemic, especially in the 2nd edition which included a Voronoi area around the pump.

name: John Speed
work: The West-Road from London to Bristol
subtitle: and Its Branches to Several of the Principal Towns
paragraph: Map roads consist of stacks of place names, showing relative distance. The title West-Road runs up the spine of the page from London.

name: Louis-Léger Vauthier
subtitle: Paris
paragraph: Population density shown by contours, an early statistical (non-geographic variable) use of a contour map.

name: John Venn
subtitle: of Propositions and Reasonings
paragraph: Popularized diagrammatic representation of logical propositions and relations. Venn himself referred to his diagrams as "Eulerian Circles."

name: John Venn
subtitle: of Propositions and Reasonings
paragraph: Popularized diagrammatic representation of logical propositions and relations. Venn himself referred to his diagrams as "Eulerian Circles."

name: Francis Amasa Walker
subtitle: Statistical Atlas of the United States
paragraph: Age pyramid (bilateral histogram).

name: Francis Amasa Walker
subtitle: Statistical Atlas of the United States
paragraph: The use of subdivided squares to show the division of population by two variables jointly (an early mosaic display).

name: William C. Woodbridge
subtitle: or View of Climates & Production
paragraph: First world isothermal chart. Woodbridge was quick to incorporate the latest scientific and educational ideas, here expanding on Humboldt's concept of isotherms to show the relationship of mean annual temperatures to world climates and crops.

name: Gustav Zeuner
subtitle: Treatises from Mathematical Statistics, Fig. 1
paragraph: Three-dimensional population surface or "stereogram'' comparing births, mortality, and census year. One of 27 graphs in this work.
